1.verse: God’s Command to Joshua - After Moses, the servant of the ·LORD [or Yahweh; “LORD” (capital letters) represents the divine name YHWH, usually pronounced “Yahweh”], died, the LORD spoke to Joshua son of Nun, Moses’ ·assistant [aide; servant].

2.verse: The LORD said, “My servant Moses is dead. Now you and all these people ·go across [get ready to cross; arise and cross] the Jordan River into the land I am giving to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel].

3.verse: I promised Moses I would give you this land [Deut. 11:24], so I will give you every place ·you go [the sole of your foot walks/treads] in the land.

4.verse: All the land from the ·desert in the south [desert; wilderness] to ·Lebanon in the north [Lebanon] will be yours. All the land from the great river, the ·Euphrates, in the east [Euphrates], to the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea ·in the west [toward the going down of the sun] will be yours, too, ·including [or which is all] the land of the Hittites [Palestine was known as “Hatti-land” (or “Hittite country”) by the Egyptians and Babylonians].

5.verse: No one will be able to ·defeat [resist; stand against] you all your life. Just as I was with Moses, so I will be with you. I will not ·leave [fail] you or ·forget [desert; forsake] you.

6.verse: “Joshua, be strong and ·brave [courageous; resolute]! You must lead these people ·so they can take [to possess/inherit] the land that I promised their fathers I would give them.

7.verse: Be strong and ·brave [courageous; resolute]. Be ·sure [careful] to obey all the ·teachings [law] my servant Moses ·gave [commanded] you. If you ·follow them exactly [do not turn from it to the right or to the left], you will be successful in everything you do.

8.verse: ·Always remember [Do not let depart from your mouth] what is written in the Book of the ·Teachings [Law]. ·Study [Meditate on] it day and night to be ·sure [careful; diligent] to obey everything that is written there. If you do this, you will be ·wise [prudent; successful] and ·successful [prosperous] ·in everything [or along life’s path; along the way].

9.verse: ·Remember that I [Have I not…?] commanded you to be strong and ·brave [courageous; resolute]. Don’t be afraid or ·discouraged [dismayed], because the LORD your God will be with you ·everywhere you go [or in all you do].”

10.verse: Joshua’s Orders to the People - Then Joshua gave orders to the ·officers [leaders] of the people:

11.verse: “Go through the camp and ·tell [command] the people, ‘Get your ·supplies [provisions] ready. ·Three days from now [or Within a few days] you will cross the Jordan River and take the land the LORD your God is ·giving you [giving you to inherit/possess].’”

12.verse: Then Joshua said to the people of Reuben, Gad, and ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh,

13.verse: “Remember what Moses, the servant of the LORD, told you [Deut. 3:18–20]. He said the LORD your God would give you ·rest [a place of rest/security] and would give you this land.

14.verse: Now your wives, children, and animals may stay here in the land Moses has given you east of the Jordan River, but your fighting men must dress for war and cross the Jordan River ahead of your brothers to help them.

15.verse: The LORD has given you a place ·to rest [of security] and will do the same for your brothers. But you must help them until they take the land the LORD their God is giving them. Then you may return to your own land east of the Jordan River, the land that Moses, the servant of the LORD, gave you [Deut. 3:18–20].”

16.verse: Then the people answered Joshua, “Anything you command us to do, we will do. Any place you send us, we will go.

17.verse: Just as we fully obeyed Moses, we will obey you. ·We ask only that [or And may] the LORD your God be with you just as he was with Moses.

18.verse: Whoever ·refuses to obey [rebels against] your commands or ·turns against [refuses to obey] you will be put to death. Just be strong and ·brave [courageous; resolute]!”

1.verse: Spies Sent to Jericho - Joshua son of Nun secretly sent out two spies from ·Acacia [Shittim; a Hebrew word meaning “acacia”] and said to them, “Go and ·look at [check out] the land, particularly at the city of Jericho.” So the men went to Jericho and ·stayed [lodged] at the house of a prostitute named Rahab.

2.verse: Someone told the king of Jericho, “[Look; Behold] Some men from Israel have come here tonight to spy out the land.”

3.verse: So the king of Jericho sent this message to Rahab: “Bring out the men who came to you and entered your house. They have come to spy out our whole land.”

4.verse: But the woman had hidden the two men. She said, “They did come here, but I didn’t know where they came from.

5.verse: In the evening, when it was time to close the city gate, they left. I don’t know where they went, but if you go quickly, maybe you can catch them.”

6.verse: (The woman had taken the men up to the roof and had hidden them there under stalks of flax that she had spread out.)

7.verse: So the king’s men went out looking for the spies on the road that leads to the ·crossings [fords] of the Jordan River. The city gate was closed just after the king’s men left the city.

8.verse: Before the spies went to sleep for the night, Rahab went up to the roof.

9.verse: She said to them, “I know the LORD has given this land to your people. ·You frighten us very much [A terror of you has fallen on us]. Everyone living in this land is ·terribly afraid of [melting away before] you

10.verse: because we have heard how the LORD dried up the ·Red Sea [or Sea of Reeds] when you came out of Egypt [Ex. 14:15–31]. We have heard how you ·destroyed [or devoted to the Lord for destruction; see 6:17; Deut. 20:15–18] Sihon and Og, two Amorite kings who lived ·east of [beyond] the Jordan.

11.verse: When we heard this, ·we were very frightened [our hearts melted]. ·Now our men are afraid to fight you [And there rose up no spirit/breath in a man because of you] because the LORD your God ·rules [is God in] the heavens above and the earth below!

12.verse: So now, ·promise [swear to] me ·before [or by] the LORD that you will show ·kindness [loyalty] to my family just as I showed ·kindness [loyalty] to you. Give me ·some proof [a sure sign; a solemn pledge] that you will do this.

13.verse: Allow my father, mother, brothers, sisters, and all of their families to live. ·Save [Rescue; Preserve] us from death.”

14.verse: The men agreed and said, “It will be our lives for your lives if you don’t tell anyone what we are doing. When the LORD gives us the land, we will be ·kind [loyal] and ·true [faithful] to you.”

15.verse: The house Rahab lived in was built on the city wall, so she used a rope to let the men down through a window.

16.verse: She said to them, “Go into the hills so the ·king’s men [pursuers] will not find you. Hide there for three days. After the ·king’s men [pursuers] return, you may go on your way.”

17.verse: The men said to her, “You must do as we say. If not, we ·cannot be responsible for keeping [will be free from] this oath you have made us swear.

18.verse: When we return to this land, you must tie this ·red [scarlet] rope in the window through which you let us down. Bring your father, mother, brothers, and all your ·family [father’s house] into your house.

19.verse: If anyone leaves your house and is killed, ·it is his own fault [his blood is on his head]. We ·cannot be responsible for him [are innocent]. If anyone in your house ·is hurt [has a hand laid on them], ·we will be responsible [his blood will be on our head].

20.verse: But if you tell anyone about this, we will be free from the oath you made us swear.”

21.verse: Rahab answered, “·I agree to this [Let it be according to your words].” So she sent them away, and they left. Then she tied the ·red [scarlet] rope in the window.

22.verse: The men left and went into the hills where they stayed for three days. The ·king’s men [pursuers] looked for them all along the road, but after three days, they returned to the city without finding them.

23.verse: Then the two men started back. They left the hills and crossed the river and came to Joshua son of Nun and told him everything that had happened to them.

24.verse: They said, “The LORD surely has given ·us all of the land [all the land into our hand]. All the people in that land are ·terribly afraid of [melting away before] us.”

1.verse: Crossing the Jordan - Early the next morning Joshua and all the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] left ·Acacia [Hebrew: Shittim; 2:1]. They traveled to the Jordan River and camped there before crossing it.

2.verse: After three days the ·officers [leaders] went through the camp

3.verse: and gave orders to the people: “When you see the priests and Levites carrying the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD your God [Ex. 25:10–22], leave where you are and follow it.

4.verse: That way you will know which way to go since you have never ·been here [passed this way] before. But do not ·follow too closely [come near it]. Stay about ·a thousand yards [two thousand cubits] behind the Ark.”

5.verse: Then Joshua told the people, “·Make yourselves holy [Consecrate yourselves], because tomorrow the LORD will do ·amazing [miraculous] things among you.”

6.verse: Joshua said to the priests, “Take the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty] and go ahead of the people.” So the priests lifted the Ark and carried it ahead of the people.

7.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Today I will begin to ·make you great [exalt/honor you] in the ·opinion [eyes] of all the Israelites so the people will know I am with you just as I was with Moses.

8.verse: ·Tell [Command] the priests who carry the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty] to go to the edge of the Jordan River and stand in the water.”

9.verse: Then Joshua said to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], “Come here and listen to the words of the LORD your God.

10.verse: Here is proof that the living God is ·with [among] you and that he will ·force [drive] out the Canaanites, Hittites, Hivites, Perizzites, Girgashites, Amorites, and Jebusites.

11.verse: [Look; Behold] The Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the Lord of the whole world will go ahead of you into the Jordan River.

12.verse: Now choose twelve men from among you, one from each of the twelve tribes of Israel.

13.verse: The priests will carry the Ark of the LORD, the ·Master [Ruler; Lord] of the whole world [Ex. 9:29], into the Jordan ahead of you. When they step into the water, it will stop. The ·river will stop flowing [waters going down will be cut off from above] and will stand up in a heap [thus reminding them of the crossing of the sea in Ex. 14].”

14.verse: So the people left ·the place where they had camped [their camp/tents], and they followed the priests who carried the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty] across the Jordan River.

15.verse: During harvest the Jordan overflows its banks. When the priests carrying the Ark came to the edge of the river and stepped into the water,

16.verse: the water ·upstream [going down from above] stopped flowing. It stood up in a heap a great distance away at Adam, a town near Zarethan. The water flowing down to the Sea of Arabah (the ·Dead [Salt] Sea) was completely cut off. So the people crossed the river ·near [opposite; across from] Jericho.

17.verse: The priests carried the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD to the middle of the river and stood there on dry ground. They waited there while ·all the people [the whole nation] of Israel walked across the Jordan River on dry land.

1.verse: Rocks to Remind the People - After all the ·people [nation] had finished crossing the Jordan, the LORD said to Joshua,

2.verse: “Choose twelve men from among the people, one from each tribe.

3.verse: ·Tell [Command; Instruct] them to get twelve rocks from the middle of the river, from where the priests stood. Carry the rocks and put them down where you ·stay [camp; lodge] tonight.”

4.verse: So Joshua ·chose [appointed] one man from each tribe. Then he called the twelve men together

5.verse: and said to them, “Go out into the river where the Ark of the LORD your God is. Each of you bring back one rock, one for each tribe of Israel, and carry it on your shoulder.

6.verse: They will be a ·sign [reminder; memorial] among you. In the future your children will ask you, ‘What do these rocks mean [to you]?’

7.verse: Tell them the water stopped flowing in the Jordan when the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD crossed the ·river [Jordan]. These rocks will always remind the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] of this [stone memorials are common in the OT; 7:26; 24:26–27; Gen. 28:18–22; 31:45–47].”

8.verse: So the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] obeyed Joshua and carried twelve rocks from the middle of the Jordan River, one rock for each of the twelve tribes of Israel, just as the LORD had commanded Joshua. They carried the rocks with them and put them down where they made their camp.

9.verse: Joshua also put twelve rocks in the middle of the Jordan River where the priests had stood while carrying the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty]. These rocks are still there today.

10.verse: The priests carrying the Ark continued standing in the middle of the river until everything was done that the LORD had commanded Joshua to tell the people, just as Moses had told Joshua. The people hurried across the river.

11.verse: After they finished crossing the river, the priests carried the Ark of the LORD to the other side as the people watched.

12.verse: The men from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh obeyed what Moses had told them. They were dressed for war, and they crossed the river ahead of the other people.

13.verse: About forty thousand soldiers prepared for war passed before the LORD as they marched across the river, going toward the plains of Jericho.

14.verse: That day the LORD ·made Joshua great [honored/exalted Joshua] in the ·opinion [eyes] of all the Israelites. They ·respected [revered; stood in awe of] Joshua all his life, just as they had ·respected [revered; stood in awe of] Moses.

15.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua,

16.verse: “Command the priests to bring the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty; Testimony] out of the river.”

17.verse: So Joshua commanded the priests, “Come up out of the Jordan.”

18.verse: Then the priests carried the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD out of the river. As soon as their feet touched dry land, the water began flowing again. The river again overflowed its banks, just as it had before they crossed.

19.verse: The people ·crossed [came up from] the Jordan on the tenth day of the first month and camped at Gilgal, ·east [on the eastern border] of Jericho.

20.verse: They carried with them the twelve rocks taken from the Jordan, and Joshua set them up at Gilgal.

21.verse: Then he spoke to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]: “In the future your children will ask you, ‘What ·do these rocks mean [are these stones]?’

22.verse: Tell them, ‘Israel crossed the Jordan River on dry land.

23.verse: The LORD your God ·caused the water to stop flowing [dried up the river before you] until you finished crossing it, just as the LORD did to the ·Red Sea [or Sea of Reeds; Ex. 14–15]. He ·stopped the water [dried it up] until we crossed it.

24.verse: The LORD did this so all ·people [the nations/people of the earth] would know ·he has great power [that the hand of the LORD is powerful] and so you would always ·respect [revere; fear] the LORD your God.’”

1.verse: All the kings of the Amorites west of the Jordan and the Canaanite kings living by the ·Mediterranean Sea [Sea] heard that the LORD dried up the Jordan River until the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] had crossed it. ·After that they were scared [Their hearts melted] and ·too afraid to face [there was no breath/spirit in them because of] the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel].

2.verse: The Israelites Are Circumcised - At that time the LORD said to Joshua, “Make knives from flint stones and circumcise [Gen. 17:7–14] the ·Israelites [sons of Israel a second time].”

3.verse: So Joshua made knives from flint stones and circumcised the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] at ·Gibeath Haaraloth [Hebrew for “Hill of Foreskins”].

4.verse: This is why Joshua circumcised the men: After the Israelites left Egypt, all the men old enough to serve in the army died in the desert on the ·way [journey] ·out of [or after leaving] Egypt.

5.verse: The men who had come out of Egypt had been circumcised, but none of those who were born in the desert on the trip from Egypt had been circumcised.

6.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] had moved about in the ·desert [wilderness] for forty years. During that time all the fighting men who had left Egypt had died because they had not obeyed the LORD [Num. 13–14]. So the LORD swore they would not see the land he had promised their ancestors to give them, a ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; a phrase describing the natural bounty of the land].

7.verse: Their sons ·took [were raised up in] their places. But none of the sons born on the trip from Egypt had been circumcised, so Joshua circumcised them.

8.verse: After all the Israelites had been circumcised, they stayed in camp until they were healed.

9.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Today I have ·removed [rolled away] the shame [disgrace; reproach] of ·your slavery in Egypt [Egypt].” So that place was named Gilgal [sounds like Hebrew for “rolled away”; 4:19], which it is still named today.

10.verse: The ·people [sons/children] of Israel were camped at Gilgal [4:19] on the plains of Jericho. It was there, on the evening of the fourteenth day of the month, they celebrated the Passover Feast [Ex. 12].

11.verse: The day after the Passover, the people ate food grown on that land: ·bread made without yeast [unleavened bread] and roasted grain.

12.verse: The day they ate this food, the manna stopped coming [Ex. 16:35]. The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] no longer got the manna from heaven. They ate the food grown in the land of Canaan that year.

13.verse: Joshua was near Jericho when he looked up and saw a man standing in front of him with a sword in his hand [Ex. 3:2—4:17; Judg. 6:11–23]. Joshua went to him and asked, “Are you ·a friend or an enemy [for us or for our enemies/adversaries]?”

14.verse: The man answered, “·I am neither [No]. I have come as the commander of the LORD’s army [God himself who comes as a warrior; Ex. 15:3].” Then Joshua bowed facedown on the ground and asked, “Does my ·master [lord] have a ·command [message] for me, his servant?”

15.verse: The commander of the LORD’s army answered, “Take off your sandals, because the place where you are standing is holy [Ex. 3:5].” So Joshua did.

1.verse: The Fall of Jericho - The people of Jericho were afraid because the Israelites were near. They closed the city gates and guarded them [Now Jericho was tightly shut because of the sons/children of Israel]. No one went into the city, and no one came out.

2.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Look, I have given ·you Jericho [Jericho into your hands], its king, and all its fighting men.

3.verse: March around the city with your ·army [fighting men] once a day for six days.

4.verse: Have seven priests carry trumpets made from ·horns of male sheep [rams’ horns] and have them march in front of the Ark. On the seventh day march around the city seven times and have the priests blow the trumpets as they march.

5.verse: They will make one long blast on the trumpets. When you hear that sound, have all the people give a loud shout. Then the walls of the city will ·fall [collapse] so the people can ·go [charge] straight into the city.”

6.verse: So Joshua son of Nun called the priests together and said to them, “Carry the Ark of the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty]. Tell seven priests to carry trumpets and march in front of it.”

7.verse: Then Joshua ordered the ·people [or army], “Now go! March around the city. The ·soldiers with weapons [armed troops; or royal guard] should march in front of the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD.”

8.verse: When Joshua finished speaking to the ·people [or army], the seven priests began marching before the LORD. They carried the seven trumpets and blew them as they marched. The priests carrying the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant/Treaty of] the LORD followed them.

9.verse: ·Soldiers with weapons [Armed troops; or The royal guard] marched in front of the priests, and ·armed men [the rear guard] walked behind the Ark. The priests were blowing their trumpets.

10.verse: But Joshua had ·told [commanded] the people not to give ·a war cry [the shout]. He said, “Don’t shout. Don’t say a word until the day I tell you. Then shout.”

11.verse: So Joshua had the Ark of the LORD carried around the city one time. Then they went back to camp for the night.

12.verse: Early the next morning Joshua got up, and the priests carried the Ark of the LORD again.

13.verse: The seven priests carried the seven trumpets and marched in front of the Ark of the LORD, blowing their trumpets. ·Soldiers with weapons [Armed troops or The royal guard] marched in front of them, and ·other soldiers [the rear guard] walked behind the Ark of the LORD. ·All this time the priests were blowing their trumpets […while the trumpets kept blowing].

14.verse: So on the second day they marched around the city one time and then went back to camp. They did this every day for six days.

15.verse: On the seventh day they got up at dawn and marched around the city, just as they had on the days before. But on that day they marched around the city seven times.

16.verse: The seventh time around the priests blew their trumpets. Then Joshua gave the command: “Now, ·shout [give the battle cry]! The LORD has given you this city!

17.verse: The city and everything in it are to be ·destroyed as an offering [devoted; set apart; 2:10] to the LORD. Only Rahab the prostitute and everyone in her house should remain alive. They must not be killed, because Rahab hid the ·two spies [messengers] we sent out [2:1–24].

18.verse: ·Don’t take any of [Keep away from] the things that are ·to be destroyed as an offering [devoted; set apart] to the LORD. If you take them and bring them into ·our camp [the camp of Israel], you yourselves will be ·destroyed [devoted/set apart for destruction], and you will bring trouble to all of Israel.

19.verse: All the silver and gold and things made from bronze and iron belong to the LORD and must ·be saved for him [go into the treasury of the LORD].”

20.verse: When the priests blew the trumpets, the ·people [army] shouted. At the sound of the trumpets and the ·people’s [army’s] shout, the walls fell, and everyone ·ran [charged] straight into the city. So the Israelites ·defeated [captured; took] that city.

21.verse: They ·completely destroyed [devoted to the Lord] with the ·sword [edge of the sword] every living thing in the city—men and women, young and old, cattle, sheep, and donkeys.

22.verse: Joshua said to the two men who had spied out the land, “Go into the prostitute’s house. Bring her out and bring out those who ·are with [belong to] her, because of the ·promise you made [oath you swore] to her.”

23.verse: So the ·two men [young men] went into the house and brought out Rahab, her father, mother, brothers, and all ·those with [who belonged to] her. They put all of her family in a safe place outside the camp of Israel.

24.verse: Then Israel burned the whole city and everything in it, but they did not burn the things made from silver, gold, bronze, and iron. These were ·saved for [put in the treasury of the house of] the LORD.

25.verse: Joshua saved Rahab the prostitute, her ·family [father’s household], and all who ·were with [belonged to] her, because Rahab had helped the men he had sent to spy out Jericho [Matt. 1:5; Heb. 11:31; James 2:25]. Rahab still lives among the Israelites today.

26.verse: Then Joshua ·made [or caused them to take] this oath: “Anyone who tries to rebuild this city of Jericho will be cursed ·by [or before] the LORD. The one who lays the foundation of this city will lose his ·oldest [firstborn] son, and the one who sets up the gates will lose his youngest son [1 Kin. 16:34].”

27.verse: So the LORD was with Joshua, and Joshua became famous through all the land.

1.verse: The Sin of Achan - But the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] ·did not obey the LORD [acted unfaithfully in regard to the devoted things; 6:17]. There was a man from the tribe of Judah named Achan. (He was the son of Carmi and grandson of Zabdi, who was the son of Zerah.) Because Achan kept some of the ·things that were to be given to the LORD [devoted things], the ·LORD became very angry [LORD’s anger burned] at the Israelites.

2.verse: Joshua sent some men from Jericho to Ai [the name means “dump,” indicating that it should have been an easy military target], which was near Beth Aven, east of Bethel. He told them, “Go to Ai and spy out the area.” So the men went to spy on Ai.

3.verse: Later they came back to Joshua and said, “There are ·only a few people [few soldiers] in Ai, so we will not need all our people to defeat them. Send only two or three thousand men to fight. ·There is no need to send [or Don’t tire out] all of our people.”

4.verse: So about three thousand men went up to Ai, but ·the people of Ai beat them badly [they fled from the men of Ai].

5.verse: The people of Ai killed about thirty-six Israelites and then chased the rest from the city gate all the way down to ·the canyon [or the stone quarries; or Shebarim], killing them as they went down the hill. When the Israelites saw this, ·they lost their courage [the heart of the people melted and became like water].

6.verse: Then Joshua tore his ·clothes in sorrow [clothes]. He ·bowed [fell] facedown on the ground before the Ark of the LORD and stayed there until evening. The ·leaders [elders] of Israel did the same thing. They also threw ·dirt [dust] on their heads [to show their sorrow].

7.verse: Then Joshua said, “·Lord GOD [or Sovereign LORD], why did you bring our people across the Jordan River ·and then let the Amorites destroy us [to give us into the hands of the Amorites]? ·We would have [If only we had] been happy to stay on the other side of the Jordan.

8.verse: Lord, ·there is nothing I can say now [what can I say now that…]. Israel has ·been beaten by [fled from; turned their back before] the enemy.

9.verse: The Canaanites and all the other people in this country will hear about this and will ·surround [encircle] and ·kill us all [cut off our name from the earth]! Then what will you do for your own great name?”

10.verse: The LORD said to Joshua, “Stand up! Why are you down on your face?

11.verse: The Israelites have sinned; they have broken the ·agreement [covenant; treaty] I commanded them to obey. They took some of the ·things I commanded them to destroy [devoted things]. They have stolen and lied and have ·taken those things for themselves [put them among their own belongings].

12.verse: That is why the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] cannot ·face [stand before] their enemies. They ·turn away from the fight and run [fled/turned their backs before their enemies], because I have ·commanded that they be destroyed [devoted them for destruction]. I will not ·help [be with] you anymore unless you destroy ·everything as I commanded [the things devoted for destruction from among] you.

13.verse: “Now go! ·Make the people holy [Consecrate the people]. Tell them, ‘·Set yourselves apart to the LORD [Consecrate yourselves] for tomorrow. The LORD, the God of Israel, says ·some of you are keeping things he commanded you to destroy [there are devoted things among you, Israel!]. You will never ·defeat [stand before] your enemies until you ·throw away those things [remove the devoted things from among you].

14.verse: “‘Tomorrow morning you must be present with your tribes. The LORD will choose one tribe to stand alone before him. Then the LORD will choose ·one family group [clan] from that tribe to stand before him. Then the LORD will choose one family from that ·family group [clan] to stand before him, person by person.

15.verse: The one who is ·keeping what should have been destroyed [caught with the devoted things] will himself be destroyed by fire. Everything ·he owns [that is his] will be destroyed with him. He has broken the ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with the LORD and has done a disgraceful thing ·among the people of [in] Israel!’”

16.verse: Early the next morning Joshua led all of Israel to present themselves in their tribes, and the LORD chose the tribe of Judah.

17.verse: So the ·family groups [clans] of Judah presented themselves, and the LORD then chose the ·family group [clan] of Zerah. When all the ·families [clan] of Zerah presented themselves, the family of Zabdi was chosen.

18.verse: And Joshua told all the men in that family to present themselves. The LORD chose Achan son of Carmi. (Carmi was the son of Zabdi, who was the son of Zerah.)

19.verse: Then Joshua said to Achan, “My son, ·tell the truth. Confess to the LORD, the God of Israel [Give glory to the LORD God of Israel and give praise to him; a solemn charge to tell the truth and confess his sins to God]. Tell me what you did, and don’t try to hide anything from me.”

20.verse: Achan answered, “It is true! I have sinned against the LORD, the God of Israel. This is what I did:

21.verse: Among the things I saw was a beautiful ·coat [robe; cloak] from ·Babylonia [Shinar] and about ·five pounds [two hundred shekels] of silver and ·more than one and one-fourth pounds of gold [a gold bar weighing fifty shekels]. I wanted these things very much for myself, so I took them. You will find them buried in the ground under my tent, with the silver underneath.”

22.verse: So Joshua sent ·men [messengers] who ran to the tent and ·found the things [behold, it was] hidden there, with the silver underneath.

23.verse: The men brought them out of the tent, took them to Joshua and all the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], and spread them out on the ground before the LORD.

24.verse: Then Joshua and all the people led Achan son of Zerah to the Valley of ·Trouble [or Achor; a Hebrew word meaning “trouble” or “disaster”]. They also took the silver, the coat, the gold bar, Achan’s sons, daughters, cattle, donkeys, sheep, tent, and everything he owned.

25.verse: Joshua said, “·I don’t know why [Why have…?] you caused so much trouble [Hebrew achor] for us, but now the LORD will bring trouble [Hebrew achor] to you.” Then all the people threw stones at Achan and his family until they died [Ex. 19:13; Lev. 24:23; Num. 15:36]. Then the people burned them.

26.verse: They piled rocks over Achan’s body, and they are still there today. That is why it is called the Valley of ·Trouble [Achor]. After this the LORD ·was no longer angry [turned from his burning anger].

1.verse: Ai Is Destroyed - Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Don’t be afraid or ·give up [be discouraged/dismayed; 1:9; 10:25]. Lead ·all your fighting men [the whole army] to Ai. I ·will help you defeat [have given into your hand] the king of Ai, his people, his city, and his land.

2.verse: You will do to Ai and its king what you did to Jericho and its king. Only this time you may ·take all the wealth [plunder its goods and livestock] and keep it for yourselves. Now ·tell some of your soldiers to set up [set] an ambush behind the city.”

3.verse: So Joshua ·led his whole army toward [and all the people rose to go up against] Ai. Then he chose thirty thousand ·of his best fighting men [brave warriors] and sent them out at night.

4.verse: Joshua gave them these orders: “·Listen carefully [Look; Behold]. You must set up an ambush behind the city. Don’t go far from it, but continue to watch and be ready.

5.verse: I and the men who are with me will march toward the city, and the men in the city will come out to fight us, just as they did before. Then we will ·turn and run away from [flee before] them.

6.verse: They will chase us away from the city, thinking we are running away from them as we did before. When we run away,

7.verse: come out from your ambush and take the city. The LORD your God will give ·you the power to win [it into your hand].

8.verse: After you take the city, burn it. ·See to it [Look; Behold]! You have your orders.”

9.verse: Then Joshua sent them to wait in ambush between Bethel and Ai, to the west of Ai. But Joshua stayed the night ·with his [among the] people.

10.verse: Early the next morning Joshua ·gathered his men together [mustered the army]. He and the ·older leaders [elders] of Israel led them up to Ai.

11.verse: All of the soldiers who were with Joshua marched up to Ai and stopped in front of the city and made camp north of it. There was a valley between them and the city.

12.verse: Then Joshua chose about five thousand men and set them in ambush in the area west of the city between Bethel and Ai.

13.verse: So the people took their positions; the main camp was north of the city, and the ·other men [rear guard; ambush] were hiding to the west. That night Joshua went down into the valley.

14.verse: Now when the king of Ai saw the army of Israel, he and his people got up early the next morning and hurried out to fight them. They went out to ·a place east of the city [or the meeting/appointed place near the Arabah/desert plain], but the king did not know soldiers were waiting in ambush behind the city.

15.verse: Joshua and all the men of Israel ·let the army of Ai push them back [pretended to be defeated]. Then they ran toward the ·desert [wilderness].

16.verse: All the men in Ai were called to chase Joshua and his men, so they ·left the city and went after them [were lured away from the city].

17.verse: All the men of Ai and Bethel chased the army of Israel [nearby Bethel must have been closely allied with Ai]. The city was left ·open [unguarded]; not a man ·stayed to protect it [was left in Ai or Bethel].

18.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Hold ·your spear [the spear/javelin that is in your hand] toward Ai, because I will give ·you that city [it into your hand].” So Joshua held ·his spear [the spear/javelin that was in his hand] toward the city of Ai.

19.verse: When the Israelites who were in ambush saw this, they quickly came out of their hiding place and hurried toward the city. They entered the city, ·took control of [captured] it, and quickly set it on fire.

20.verse: When the men of Ai looked back, ·they saw [look; behold] smoke rising [into the sky] from their city. At the same time the Israelites stopped running and turned against ·the men of Ai [their pursuers], who could not escape in any direction.

21.verse: When Joshua and all ·his men [Israel] saw that the ·army [men in ambush] had taken control of the city and saw the smoke rising from it, they stopped running and turned to ·fight [strike down] the men of Ai.

22.verse: The men who were in ambush also came out of the city to help with the fight. So the men of Ai were caught between the armies of Israel. None of the enemy escaped. The Israelites ·fought [struck them down] until not one of the men of Ai ·was left alive [either survived or escaped], except

23.verse: the king of Ai, and they brought him to Joshua.

24.verse: A Review of the Fighting - During the fighting the army of Israel chased the men of Ai into the fields and ·desert [wilderness] and killed all of them. Then they went back to Ai and killed everyone there.

25.verse: All the people of Ai died that day, twelve thousand men and women.

26.verse: Joshua ·had held his spear toward Ai, as a sign to destroy the city, and did not draw it back [did not draw back the hand that held his spear/javelin] until all the people of Ai were ·destroyed [devoted to destruction; 2:10; 6:17].

27.verse: The people of Israel kept for themselves the animals and the ·other things the people of Ai had owned [plunder of the city], as the LORD had commanded Joshua to do.

28.verse: Then Joshua burned the city of Ai and made it [permanently; forever] a pile of ruins. And it is still like that today.

29.verse: Joshua hanged the king of Ai on a tree and left him there until evening [an act of humiliation and shame; Deut. 21:23]. At sunset Joshua told his men to take the king’s body down from the tree and to throw it down at the city gate. Then they covered it with a pile of rocks [7:26], which is still there today.

30.verse: Joshua built an altar for the LORD, the God of Israel, on Mount Ebal, as

31.verse: Moses, the LORD’s servant, had commanded the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]. Joshua built the altar as it was explained in the Book of the ·Teachings [Law] of Moses. It was made from ·uncut [whole] stones; no tool was ever used on them. On that altar the Israelites offered burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD and ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1].

32.verse: There Joshua ·wrote [made a copy of] the teachings of Moses on stones for all the ·people [sons; children] of Israel to see.

33.verse: The elders, officers, judges, and all the Israelites were there; ·Israelites and non-Israelites [native-born and foreigners] were all standing around the Ark of the ·Agreement with [Covenant of] the LORD in front of the priests, the Levites who had carried the Ark. Half of the people stood in front of Mount Ebal, and half stood in front of Mount Gerizim. This was the way the LORD’s servant Moses had earlier commanded the people to be blessed [Deut. 11:29; 27:11–26].

34.verse: Then Joshua read all the words of the ·teachings [law; instruction], the blessings and the curses, exactly as they were written in the Book of the ·Teachings [Law].

35.verse: All the Israelites were gathered together—men, women, and children—along with the ·non-Israelites [foreigners] who lived among them. Joshua read every ·command [word] that Moses had given.

1.verse: The Gibeonite Trickery - All the kings ·west of [beyond] the Jordan River heard about these things: the kings of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites. They lived in the ·mountains [hill country] and ·on the western foothills [or in the lowlands/Shephelah] and along the whole ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea coast.

2.verse: So all these kings gathered to fight Joshua and the Israelites.

3.verse: When the ·people [inhabitants] of Gibeon heard ·how Joshua had defeated [what Joshua had done to] Jericho and Ai,

4.verse: they decided to trick the Israelites. They gathered old sacks and old ·leather wine bags [wineskins] that were cracked and mended, and they put them on the backs of their donkeys.

5.verse: They put ·old [worn and patched] sandals on their feet and wore ·old [ragged] clothes, and they took some dry, ·moldy [or crumbling] bread.

6.verse: Then they went to Joshua in the camp near Gilgal [4:19]. The men said to Joshua and the ·Israelites [men of Israel], “We have traveled from a faraway country. Make a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with us.”

7.verse: The ·Israelites [men of Israel] said to these Hivites, “Maybe you live near us. How can we make a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with you [Deut. 20:10–18]?”

8.verse: The Hivites said to Joshua, “We are your servants.” But Joshua asked, “Who are you? Where do you come from?”

9.verse: The men answered, “We are your servants who have come from a far country, because we heard of the ·fame [reputation; name] of the LORD your God. We heard about what he has done and everything he did in Egypt.

10.verse: We heard that he defeated the two kings of the Amorites ·from the east side of [who were beyond] the Jordan River—Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan who ·ruled [was] in Ashtaroth.

11.verse: So our elders and ·our people [all the inhabitants of our country] said to us, ‘Take ·food [provisions] for your journey and go and meet ·the Israelites [them]. Tell them, “We are your servants. Make a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with us.” ’

12.verse: “Look at our bread. On the day we left home to come to you it was warm and fresh, but now [look; behold] it is dry and ·moldy [or crumbling].

13.verse: Look at our ·leather wine bags [wineskins]. They were new and filled with wine, but now they ·are cracked and old [are ripped; or have burst]. Our clothes and sandals are worn out from the long journey.”

14.verse: The men of Israel ·tasted [or examined; took some of] the bread, but they did not ·ask the LORD what to do [seek the LORD’s guidance].

15.verse: So Joshua agreed to make peace with the Gibeonites and to let them live. And the leaders of the Israelites ·swore an oath to keep the agreement [swore to them].

16.verse: Three days after they had made the ·agreement [covenant; treaty], the Israelites learned that the Gibeonites ·lived nearby [were neighbors and lived in their midst].

17.verse: So the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went to where they lived and on the third day came to their cities: Gibeon, Kephirah, Beeroth, and Kiriath Jearim.

18.verse: But the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] did not attack those cities, because they had ·made a promise [sworn] to them before the LORD, the God of Israel. ·All the Israelites [The whole assembly/congregation] grumbled against the leaders.

19.verse: But [all] the leaders answered, “We ·have given our promise [swore (an oath)] before the LORD, the God of Israel, so we cannot ·attack [touch] them now.

20.verse: This is what we must do. We must let them live. Otherwise, ·God’s anger [wrath] will ·be against [come upon] us for breaking the oath we swore to them.

21.verse: So let them live, but they will cut wood and carry water for ·our people [the whole congregation].” ·So the leaders kept their promise to them [or…as the leaders had decided].

22.verse: Joshua called for the Gibeonites and asked, “Why did you ·lie to [deceive; trick] us? ·Your land was near our camp [You live among us], but you told us you were from a far country.

23.verse: Now, you will be placed under a curse to ·be our slaves [never cease being slaves/servants]. You will have to cut wood and carry water for the house of my God.”

24.verse: The Gibeonites answered Joshua, “We lied to you because we were afraid you would kill us. ·We heard [It was clearly/with certainty reported to your servants] that the LORD your God commanded his servant Moses to give you all of this land and to ·kill [destroy] all the people who lived in it [Deut. 20:15–18]. That is why we did this.

25.verse: Now [look; behold] ·you can decide what [we are in your hands] to do with us, whatever you think is right.”

26.verse: So Joshua saved their lives by not allowing the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] to kill them,

27.verse: but he made the Gibeonites slaves. They cut wood and carried water for the Israelites, and they did it for the altar of the LORD—·wherever he chose it to be [at the place that he would choose; 1 Sam. 4:3; 1 Kin. 9:3]. They are still doing this today [2 Sam. 21:1–14].

1.verse: The Sun Stands Still - At this time Adoni-Zedek king of Jerusalem heard that Joshua had ·defeated [captured] Ai and ·completely destroyed it [devoted it to destruction; 2:10; 6:17], doing to Ai and its king as he had also done to Jericho and its king. The king also learned that the Gibeonites had made a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with Israel and that they ·lived nearby [were living among them; or had become allies].

2.verse: Adoni-Zedek and his people were very afraid because of this. Gibeon was not a little town like Ai; it was a ·large [great; important] city, ·as big as a city that had a king [like one of the royal cities], and all its men were good fighters.

3.verse: So Adoni-Zedek king of Jerusalem sent a message to Hoham king of Hebron, Piram king of Jarmuth, Japhia king of Lachish, and Debir king of Eglon [five major cities in the southern mountains]. He begged them,

4.verse: “Come with me and help me attack Gibeon, which has made a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with Joshua and the Israelites.”

5.verse: Then these five Amorite kings—the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon—gathered their armies, went to Gibeon, surrounded it, and attacked it.

6.verse: The Gibeonites sent this message to Joshua in his camp at Gilgal [4:19]: “Don’t ·let us, your servants, be destroyed [abandon your servants]. Come quickly and help us! Save us! All the Amorite kings from the mountains have joined their armies and are fighting against us.”

7.verse: So Joshua marched out of Gilgal with his whole army, including his best fighting men.

8.verse: The LORD said to Joshua, “Don’t be afraid of those armies, because I will ·hand them over to you [give them into your hand]. None of them will be able to stand against you.”

9.verse: Joshua and his army marched all night from Gilgal for a surprise attack.

10.verse: The LORD ·confused those armies [threw them into a panic] when Israel attacked, so Israel defeated them in a great victory at Gibeon. They chased them along the road going up to Beth Horon and ·killed men [struck them down] all the way to Azekah and Makkedah.

11.verse: As they chased the enemy down the Beth Horon Pass to Azekah, the LORD threw large hailstones on them from the ·sky [heavens] and killed them. More people were killed by the hailstones than by the Israelites’ swords.

12.verse: On the day that the LORD gave up the Amorites to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], Joshua stood before all the people of Israel and said to the LORD: “Sun, stand still over Gibeon. Moon, stand still over the Valley of Aijalon.”

13.verse: So the sun stood still, and the moon stopped until the ·people [nation] ·defeated [took vengeance on] their enemies. ·These words are [Is this not…?] written in the ·Book [Scroll] of Jashar [meaning “Upright One”; an extrabiblical account of Israel’s wars, now lost; 2 Sam. 1:18]. The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and waited to go down for a full day.

14.verse: ·That has never happened at any time [There has been no day like it] before that day or since. That was the day the LORD listened to a human being. Truly the LORD was fighting for Israel!

15.verse: After this, Joshua and his army went back to the camp at Gilgal.

16.verse: During the fight the five kings ran away and hid in a cave ·near [at] Makkedah,

17.verse: but someone found them hiding in the cave at Makkedah and told Joshua.

18.verse: So he said, “·Cover the opening of the cave with large rocks [Roll large stones against the mouth of the cave]. Put some men there to guard it,

19.verse: but don’t stay there yourselves. Continue chasing the enemy and attacking them from behind. Don’t let them get to their cities, because the LORD your God will ·hand them over to you [give them into your hand].”

20.verse: So Joshua and the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] ·killed the enemy [finished slaying them with a very great slaughter], but a ·few [remnant; few survivors] were able to get back to their strong, walled cities.

21.verse: After the fighting, Joshua’s men came back safely to him at Makkedah. No one ·was brave enough to say a word against [or suffered even a scratch on his tongue; the Hebrew idiom “sharpened/scratched his tongue” may mean to threaten with words or to suffer a minor injury] the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel].

22.verse: Joshua said, “Move the ·rocks that are covering the opening [mouth] of the cave and bring those five kings out to me.”

23.verse: So Joshua’s men brought the five kings out of the cave—the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon.

24.verse: When they brought the five kings out to Joshua, he called for all his men. He said to the commanders of his army, “Come here! Put your feet on the necks of these kings.” So they came close and put their feet on their necks [a gesture of triumph and dominance; 2 Sam. 22:41; Ps. 18:41].

25.verse: Joshua said to his men, “Be strong and brave! Don’t be afraid or ·discouraged [dismayed; 1:9; 8:1], because I will show you what the LORD will do to the enemies you will fight in the future.”

26.verse: Then Joshua killed the five kings and hung their bodies on five trees [an act of humiliation and shame; Deut. 21:23], where he left them until evening.

27.verse: At sunset Joshua ·told [commanded] his men to take the bodies down from the trees. Then they threw them into the same cave where they had been hiding and covered the opening of the cave with large rocks, which are still there today.

28.verse: That day Joshua ·defeated [captured] Makkedah. He killed the king and ·completely destroyed [devoted to destruction; 2:10; 6:17; 10:1] all the people in that city as an offering to the LORD; no one was left alive. He did the same thing to the king of Makkedah that he had done to the king of Jericho.

29.verse: Defeating Southern Cities - Joshua and all the Israelites traveled from Makkedah to Libnah and attacked it.

30.verse: The LORD handed over the city and its king. They ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] every person in the city; no one was left alive. And they did the same thing to that king that they had done to the king of Jericho.

31.verse: Then Joshua and all the Israelites left Libnah and went to Lachish, which they ·surrounded [took up positions against; besieged] and attacked.

32.verse: The LORD ·handed over Lachish [gave Lachish into their hand] on the second day. The Israelites ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] everyone in that city just as they had done to Libnah.

33.verse: During this same time Horam king of Gezer came to help Lachish, but Joshua also defeated him and his army; no one was left alive.

34.verse: Then Joshua and all the Israelites went from Lachish to Eglon. They ·surrounded [took up positions against; besieged] Eglon, attacked it, and

35.verse: captured it the same day. They ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] all its people and ·completely destroyed [devoted to destruction; 6:17; 10:28] everything in it as an offering to the LORD, just as they had done to Lachish.

36.verse: Then Joshua and the Israelites went from Eglon to Hebron and attacked it,

37.verse: capturing it and all the little towns near it. The Israelites ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] its king, its surrounding towns, and everyone in Hebron; no one was left alive there. Just as they had done to Eglon, they ·completely destroyed [devoted to destruction; 6:17; 10:28] the city and all its people as an offering to the LORD.

38.verse: Then Joshua and the Israelites went back to Debir and attacked it.

39.verse: They captured that city, its king, and all the little towns near it, ·completely destroying [striking with the edge of the sword and devoting to destruction; 10:37] everyone in Debir as an offering to the LORD; no one was left alive there. Israel did to Debir and its king just as they had done to Libnah and its king, just as they had done to Hebron.

40.verse: So Joshua ·defeated [struck down] ·all the kings of the cities of these areas [the whole region/land]: the ·mountains [hill country], ·southern Canaan [the Negev], the ·western foothills [lowlands; Shephelah], and the slopes [and all their kings]. The LORD, the God of Israel, had ·told [commanded] Joshua to ·completely destroy [devote to destruction; 2:10; 6:17] all ·the people [that breathed] as an offering to the LORD, so he left no one alive in those places.

41.verse: Joshua captured all the cities from Kadesh Barnea to Gaza, and from Goshen to Gibeon.

42.verse: He captured all these cities and their kings ·on one trip [in one campaign; at one time], because the LORD, the God of Israel, was fighting for Israel.

43.verse: Then Joshua and all the Israelites returned to their camp at Gilgal [4:19].

1.verse: Defeating Northern Kings - When Jabin king of Hazor [the largest and best fortified of the Canaanite cities] heard about all that had happened, he sent messages to Jobab king of Madon, to the king of Shimron, and to the king of Acshaph.

2.verse: He sent messages to the kings in the northern ·mountains [hill country] and also to the kings in the ·Jordan Valley [or Arabah] south of ·Lake Galilee [Kinnereth] and in the ·western foothills [lowlands; Shephelah]. He sent a message to the king of ·Naphoth [or the heights of] Dor in the west [the coastal plain south of Mount Carmel]

3.verse: and to the kings of the Canaanites in the east and in the west. He sent messages to the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, and Jebusites in the ·mountains [hill country]. Jabin also sent one to the Hivites, who lived below Mount Hermon in the area of Mizpah [a coalition of the northern cities of Palestine].

4.verse: So the armies of all these kings came together with their horses and chariots [a great challenge to the Israelites, who only had foot soldiers]. There were as many soldiers as grains of sand on the seashore [Gen. 22:17].

5.verse: All of these kings met together at the waters of Merom [probably modern Meirun, eight miles northwest of the Sea of Galilee], joined their armies together into one camp, and made plans to fight against the Israelites.

6.verse: Then the LORD said to Joshua, “Don’t be afraid of them, because at this time tomorrow I will give them to you. You will ·cripple [hamstring] their horses and burn all their chariots.”

7.verse: So Joshua and his whole army surprised the enemy [10:9] by attacking them at the waters of Merom.

8.verse: The LORD ·handed them over to [gave them into the hand of] Israel. They chased them to Greater Sidon, Misrephoth Maim, and the Valley of Mizpah in the east [locations north and west of the battle]. Israel fought until none of the enemy was left alive.

9.verse: Joshua did what the LORD said to do; he ·crippled [hamstrung] their horses and burned their chariots [Israel did not take the horses and chariots to use themselves, in order to show their trust in God; Ps. 20:7].

10.verse: Then Joshua went back and captured the city of Hazor and ·killed [struck with the sword] its king. (Hazor had been the leader of all the kingdoms that fought against Israel.)

11.verse: Israel ·killed [struck with the sword] everyone in Hazor, ·completely destroying them [devoting them to destruction; 2:10; 6:21]; no one was left ·alive [that breathed]. Then they burned Hazor itself.

12.verse: Joshua captured all of these cities, ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] all of their kings, and ·completely destroyed [devoted to destruction; v. 11] everything in these cities. He did this just as Moses, the servant of the LORD, had commanded.

13.verse: But the Israelites did not burn any cities that were built on their mounds [so Israel could immediately occupy these strategically important cities; Deut. 6:10–11], except Hazor; only that city was burned by Joshua.

14.verse: The ·people [sons; children] of Israel kept for themselves ·everything [the plunder/spoil] they found in the cities, including all the animals. But they ·killed [struck with the edge of the sword] all the people there; they left no one ·alive [that breathed].

15.verse: Long ago the LORD had commanded his servant Moses to do this, and then Moses had commanded Joshua to do it [Deut. 7:1–6; 20:16–18]. Joshua ·did everything [left nothing undone that] the LORD had commanded Moses.

16.verse: So Joshua defeated all the people in the land [a general statement, since not every city was taken; 17:16; Judg. 1]. He had control of the mountains and ·the area of southern Canaan [all the Negev], all the areas of Goshen, the ·western foothills [lowlands; Shephelah], and the ·Jordan Valley [or Arabah]. He controlled the ·mountains [hill country] of Israel and ·all the hills near them [or its lowlands/Shephelah].

17.verse: ·Joshua controlled all the land from […from] Mount Halak near ·Edom [Seir] to Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon, below Mount Hermon. Joshua also captured all the kings in the land and killed them.

18.verse: He ·fought [waged war] against them for ·many years [a long time; many days].

19.verse: The people of only one city in all the land had made a peace ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with Israel—the Hivites living in Gibeon. All the other cities were defeated in war.

20.verse: The LORD ·made those people stubborn [hardened their hearts; Ex. 8:15] so they would fight against Israel and ·he could completely destroy them [would be devoted to destruction; 2:10; 6:17] without mercy. This is what the LORD had commanded Moses to do.

21.verse: Now Joshua fought the Anakites [or Anakim; Num. 13:33] who lived in the ·mountains [hill country] of Hebron, Debir, Anab, Judah, and Israel, and he completely destroyed them and their towns.

22.verse: There were no Anakites left living in the land of the Israelites ·and only a few were left [or though some remained] in Gaza, Gath, and Ashdod.

23.verse: Joshua took control of all the ·land of Israel [land] as the LORD had ·told Moses to do [or promised Moses] long ago. He gave the land to Israel, ·because he had promised it to them [as an inheritance]. ·Then Joshua divided the land among the tribes of Israel […according to their tribal divisions], and ·there was peace in the land [the land had rest from war].

1.verse: Kings Defeated by Israel - The Israelites took control of the land east of the Jordan River from the Arnon ·Ravine [Gorge; Valley; enters the middle of Dead Sea from the east] to Mount Hermon [in the far north] and all the land along the eastern side of the ·Jordan Valley [or Arabah]. These ·lands belonged to the kings [were the kings of the land] whom the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] defeated.

2.verse: Sihon king of the Amorites [Num. 21:21–30; Deut. 1:4; 2:24–37; 29:7–8] ·lived in [or ruled] the city of Heshbon and ruled the land from Aroer ·at [or on the edge/rim of] the Arnon ·Ravine [Gorge; Valley] to the Jabbok River [flows from the northeast into the Jordan about 20 miles north of the Dead Sea]. His land started in the middle of the ravine, which was their border with the Ammonites. Sihon ruled over half the land of Gilead [the region east of the Jordan between Galilee and just north of the Dead Sea]

3.verse: and over the eastern side of the ·Jordan Valley [or Arabah] from Lake ·Galilee [Kinnereth] to the ·Dead Sea [Sea of Arabah, the Salt Sea]. And he ruled from Beth Jeshimoth south to the slopes of Pisgah [Deut. 34:1].

4.verse: Og king of Bashan was one of the ·last [remnant] of the Rephaites. He ·ruled [or lived in] the land in Ashtaroth and Edrei [cities east and southeast of Galilee].

5.verse: He ruled over Mount Hermon, Salecah, and all the area of Bashan [east and northeast of Galilee] up to ·where the people of Geshur and Maacah lived [the border of the Geshurites and the Maacathites]. Og also ruled half the land of Gilead up to the border of Sihon king of Heshbon.

6.verse: The LORD’s servant Moses and the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] defeated all these kings, and Moses gave that land to the tribes of Reuben and Gad and to ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh as their own [13:8–32; Deut. 3:12–13].

7.verse: Joshua and the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] also defeated kings in the land west of the Jordan River. He gave the people the land ·and divided it among the twelve tribes to be their own [according to their tribal divisions]. It was between Baal Gad in the Valley of Lebanon [the far north] and Mount Halak near ·Edom [Seir; the far south].

8.verse: This included the ·mountains [hill country], the ·western foothills [lowlands; Shephelah], the ·Jordan Valley [Arabah], the slopes, the ·desert [wilderness], and ·southern Canaan [the Negev]. This was the land where the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites had lived. The Israelites defeated the king of each of the following cities:

9.verse: ·Jericho [the king of Jericho, one; and so throughout the list], Ai (near Bethel),

10.verse: Jerusalem, Hebron,

11.verse: Jarmuth, Lachish,

12.verse: Eglon, Gezer,

13.verse: Debir, Geder,

14.verse: Hormah, Arad,

15.verse: Libnah, Adullam,

16.verse: Makkedah, Bethel,

23.verse: Dor (in Naphoth Dor), Goyim in Gilgal, and

24.verse: Tirzah. The total number of kings was thirty-one.

1.verse: Land Still to Be Taken - When Joshua was very old, the LORD said to him, “Joshua, you have grown old, but there is still much land for you to ·take [possess; conquer].

2.verse: This is what is left: the regions of Geshur and of the Philistines [the southern coastline along the Mediterranean Sea];

3.verse: the area from the Shihor River [Wadi el-Arish located below Gaza] ·at the border [east; in front] of Egypt ·to [to the border of] Ekron in the north, which ·belongs to the Canaanites [is regarded/counted as Canaanite]; the five Philistine ·leaders [rulers; lords] at Gaza, Ashdod, Ashkelon, Gath, and Ekron; the Avvites,

4.verse: ·who live south of the Canaanite land, from Arah of the Sidonians [the people of the northern coastal plains] to Aphek, to the border of the Amorites;

5.verse: the ·Gebalites [inhabitants of the city of Byblos, located north of modern Beirut], and the area of Lebanon east of Baal Gad below Mount Hermon to Lebo Hamath.

6.verse: “The Sidonians are living in the hill country from Lebanon to Misrephoth Maim, but I will ·force [drive] all of them out ahead of the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]. Be sure to ·remember this land when you divide the land among the Israelites [allocate this land to Israel as an inheritance], as I ·told [commanded] you.

7.verse: “Now divide the land ·among [as an inheritance among] the nine tribes and ·West [the half-tribe of] Manasseh.”

8.verse: Dividing the Land - ·East Manasseh and [With it; referring to the other half-tribe of Manasseh] the tribes of Reuben and Gad had received their ·land [inheritance]. The LORD’s servant Moses had given them the land east of the Jordan River [Deut. 3:18–20].

9.verse: ·Their land started at [From] Aroer at the Arnon ·Ravine [Valley; 12:1] ·and continued to [or including] the town in the middle of the ravine, and it included the whole ·plain [or plateau] from Medeba to Dibon.

10.verse: All the towns ruled by Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled in the city of Heshbon, were in that land. The land continued to the area where the Ammonites lived.

11.verse: Gilead [12:3] was also there, as well as the area where the people of Geshur and Maacah lived, and all of Mount Hermon and Bashan as far as Salecah.

12.verse: All the kingdom of Og king of Bashan was in the land [12:4–5]. Og was ·one of the last [from the remnant] of the Rephaites, and in the past he ruled in Ashtaroth and Edrei. Moses had ·defeated [struck] them and had taken their land.

13.verse: Because the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] did not ·force [drive] out the people of Geshur and Maacah, they still live among the Israelites today.

14.verse: The tribe of Levi was the only one that ·did not get any land [he gave no inheritance]. Instead, they were given all the burned sacrifices [a portion of the food offerings] made to the LORD, the God of Israel, as he had promised them [14:3–4; Num. 3:45; 35:1–8].

15.verse: Moses had given each ·family group [clan] from the tribe of Reuben some land:

16.verse: Theirs was the land from Aroer near the Arnon ·Ravine [Valley; 12:1] to the town of Medeba, including the whole plain and the town in the middle of the ·ravine [valley];

17.verse: Heshbon and all ·the [its] towns on the plain: Dibon, Bamoth Baal, and Beth Baal Meon,

19.verse: Kiriathaim, Sibmah, Zereth Shahar on the hill in the valley,

20.verse: Beth Peor, the ·hills [slopes] of Pisgah, and Beth Jeshimoth.

21.verse: So that land included all the towns on the plain and all the area that Sihon king of the Amorites had ruled from the town of Heshbon. Moses had defeated him along with the leaders of the Midianites, including Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba. All these ·leaders [princes] ·fought together with [or were subjects of] Sihon and lived in that country.

22.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] ·killed [slayed with the sword] many people during the fighting, including Balaam of Beor, who ·tried to use magic to tell the future [practiced divination; Num. 22–24].

23.verse: The land given to Reuben stopped at the shore of the Jordan River. So the ·land [inheritance] given to the ·family groups [clans] of Reuben included all these towns and their villages.

24.verse: This is the land Moses gave to the tribe of Gad, to all its ·family groups [clans]:

25.verse: the land of Jazer and all the towns of Gilead; half the land of the Ammonites that went as far as Aroer near Rabbah;

26.verse: the area from Heshbon to Ramath Mizpah and Betonim; the area from Mahanaim to the land of Debir;

27.verse: in the valley, Beth Haram, Beth Nimrah, Succoth, and Zaphon, the ·other land [rest of the kingdom] Sihon king of Heshbon had ruled east of the Jordan River and continuing to the end of Lake ·Galilee [Kinnereth].

28.verse: ·All this land went to [This is the inheritance of] the ·family groups [clans] of Gad, including all these towns and their villages.

29.verse: This is the land Moses had given to ·East [the half-tribe of] Manasseh. Half of all the ·family groups [clans] in the tribe of Manasseh were given this land:

30.verse: The land started at Mahanaim and included all of Bashan [12:4] and the land ruled by Og king of Bashan; all the towns of Jair in Bashan, sixty cities in all;

31.verse: half of Gilead, Ashtaroth, and Edrei, the cities where Og king of Bashan had ruled. All this went to the ·family [or descendants; children/sons] of Makir son of Manasseh, and half of all his ·sons [descendants] were given this land.

32.verse: Moses had given this land to these tribes on the plains of Moab across the Jordan River east of Jericho [Num. 32:32, 39–42].

33.verse: But Moses had given no land to the tribe of Levi because the LORD, the God of Israel, promised that he himself would be the gift for the Levites [v. 14; 18:7; Num. 18:20; Deut. 18:1–8].

1.verse: Eleazar the priest [the son of Aaron; Ex. 28:1; Num. 34:17], Joshua son of Nun, and the ·leaders [heads of the fathers] of all the tribes of Israel decided what land to give to the people in the land of Canaan.

2.verse: The LORD had commanded Moses long ago how he wanted the people to choose their land. The people of the nine-and-a-half tribes threw lots [casting lots left the decision to God; the Urim and Thummim may have been used; Ex. 28:30; Num. 27:21] to decide which land they would receive.

3.verse: Moses had already given the two-and-a-half tribes their land east of the Jordan River. But the tribe of Levi was not given any ·land [inheritance] like the others.

4.verse: The sons of Joseph had ·divided into [become] two tribes—Manasseh and Ephraim. The tribe of Levi was not given any ·land [inheritance]. It was given only some towns in which to live and pastures for its ·animals [cattle and property].

5.verse: The LORD had told Moses how to give the land to the tribes of Israel, and the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] divided the land.

6.verse: Caleb’s Land - One day ·some men from the tribe of Judah [the sons/descendants of Judah] went to Joshua at Gilgal [4:19]. Among them was Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite. He said to Joshua, “You remember what the LORD said at Kadesh Barnea when he was speaking to ·the prophet Moses [Moses, the man of God] about you and me [Num. 14:6–9, 24, 30].

7.verse: Moses, the LORD’s servant, sent me to ·look at [spy out] the land where we were going. I was forty years old then. When I came back, I ·told Moses what I thought about the land [brought back an honest report; brought him word as it was in my heart; Num. 13:30].

8.verse: The other men who went with me ·frightened the people [made the heart of the people melt; Num. 13:27–29; 14:1–4], but I ·fully believed the LORD would allow us to take the land [or remained loyal to the LORD; followed the LORD].

9.verse: So that day Moses ·promised [swore to; made an oath to] me, ‘The land where ·you went [your foot has trodden] will become your ·land [inheritance], and your children will own it forever. I will give you that land because you ·fully believed in [or remained loyal to; followed] the LORD, my God.’

10.verse: “Now then, [look; behold] the LORD has kept his promise. He has kept me alive for forty-five years from the time he said this to Moses during the time ·we all [Israel] wandered in the ·desert [wilderness]. Now ·here [look; behold] I am, eighty-five years old.

11.verse: I am still as strong today as I was the day Moses sent me out, ·and I am just as ready to fight now as I was then [my strength then is like my strength now, for battle and for going out and coming in].

12.verse: So give me the mountain country the LORD promised me that day long ago. Back then you heard that the ·Anakite people [Anakim] lived there and the cities were large and well protected. But now with the LORD helping me, I will ·force [drive] them out, just as the LORD said.”

13.verse: Joshua blessed Caleb son of Jephunneh and gave him the city of Hebron [southwest of Jerusalem in the Judean hills] as his ·own [inheritance].

14.verse: Hebron still ·belongs to [remains the inheritance of] the family of Caleb son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite because he ·had faith and obeyed [remained loyal to; wholly followed] the LORD, the God of Israel.

15.verse: (In the past Hebron was called Kiriath Arba, named for Arba, the greatest man among the Anakites.) After this ·there was peace in the land [the land had rest from war].

1.verse: Land for Judah - The ·land that was given to [allotment for] the tribe of Judah was divided among all the ·family groups [clans]. It went all the way to the ·Desert [Wilderness] of Zin in the far south, at the border of Edom.

2.verse: The southern border of Judah’s land started at the south end of the ·Dead [Salt] Sea

3.verse: and went south of ·Scorpion Pass [or the ascent of Akrabbim] to Zin. From there it passed to the south of Kadesh Barnea and continued past Hezron to Addar. From Addar it turned and went to Karka.

4.verse: It continued to Azmon, the ·brook [stream; wadi] of Egypt, and then to the ·Mediterranean Sea [Sea]. This was the southern border.

5.verse: The eastern border was the shore of the ·Dead [Salt] Sea, as far as the mouth of the Jordan River. The northern border started at the bay of the sea at the mouth of the Jordan River.

6.verse: Then it went to Beth Hoglah and continued north of Beth Arabah to the stone of Bohan son of Reuben.

7.verse: Then ·the northern border went [the border went up] through the Valley of Achor to Debir where it turned toward the north and went to Gilgal. Gilgal is ·across from the road that goes through [opposite] Adummim Pass, on the south side of the ·ravine [valley; gorge]. The border continued to the waters of En Shemesh and stopped at En Rogel.

8.verse: Then it went through the Valley of ·Ben [the Son of] Hinnom, next to the southern ·side [slope] of the Jebusite city (·which is called [that is,] Jerusalem). There the border went to the top of the hill on the west side of Hinnom Valley, at the northern end of the Valley of ·Giants [Raphaim].

9.verse: From there it went to the spring of the waters of Nephtoah and then it went to the cities near Mount Ephron. There it turned and went toward Baalah, ·which is called [that is,] Kiriath Jearim.

10.verse: At Baalah the border turned west and went toward Mount Seir. It continued along the ·north side [northern slope] of Mount Jearim (also called Kesalon) and ·came [or descended] to Beth Shemesh. From there it ·went past [or crossed to] Timnah

11.verse: to the ·hill north [northern slope] of Ekron. Then it turned toward Shikkeron and ·went past [or crossed to] Mount Baalah and continued on to Jabneel, ending at the sea.

12.verse: The ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea was the western border. Inside these borders lived the ·family groups [clans] of Judah.

13.verse: The LORD had commanded Joshua to give Caleb son of Jephunneh ·part of the land [a portion] in Judah, so he gave Caleb the town of Kiriath Arba, ·also called [that is,] Hebron [14:13]. (Arba was the father of Anak.)

14.verse: Caleb ·forced [drove] out the three ·Anakite families [sons of Anak] living in Hebron: Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai, the descendants of Anak.

15.verse: Then he left there and went to fight against the people living in Debir. (In the past Debir had been called Kiriath Sepher.)

16.verse: Caleb said, “I will give Acsah, my daughter, as a wife to the man who attacks and captures the city of Kiriath Sepher.”

17.verse: Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s brother, captured the city, so Caleb gave his daughter Acsah to Othniel to be his wife.

18.verse: When Acsah came to ·Othniel [him; could be Othniel or Caleb], she ·told him to ask [or asked] her father for a field. So Acsah went to her father. When she got down from her donkey, Caleb asked her, “What do you want?”

19.verse: Acsah answered, “·Do me a special favor [Give me a blessing]. Since you have given me land in ·southern Canaan [the Negev], also give me springs of water.” So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.

20.verse: ·The tribe of Judah got the land God had promised them [This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Judah]. ·Each family group got part of the land […according to its clans].

21.verse: The tribe of Judah got all these towns in the ·southern part of Canaan [extreme south; Negev] near the border of Edom: Kabzeel, Eder, Jagur,

25.verse: Hazor Hadattah, Kerioth Hezron (also called Hazor),

32.verse: Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain, and Rimmon. There were twenty-nine towns and their villages.

33.verse: The tribe of Judah got these towns in the ·western foothills [lowlands]: Eshtaol, Zorah, Ashnah,

36.verse: Shaaraim, Adithaim, and Gederah (also called Gederothaim). There were fourteen towns and their villages.

37.verse: Judah was also given Zenan, Hadashah, Migdal Gad,

41.verse: Gederoth, Beth Dagon, Naamah, and Makkedah. There were sixteen towns and their villages.

42.verse: Judah was also given Libnah, Ether, Ashan,

44.verse: Keilah, Aczib, and Mareshah. There were nine towns and their villages.

45.verse: Judah was also given Ekron and all the small towns and villages near it;

46.verse: the area west of Ekron and all the villages and small towns near Ashdod;

47.verse: Ashdod and the small towns and villages around it; the villages and small towns around Gaza as far as the ·brook [stream; wadi] of Egypt and along the coast of the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea.

48.verse: Judah was also given these towns in the ·mountains [hill country]: Shamir, Jattir, Socoh,

51.verse: Goshen, Holon, and Giloh. There were eleven towns and their villages.

52.verse: They were also given Arab, Dumah, Eshan,

54.verse: Humtah, Kiriath Arba (also called Hebron), and Zior. There were nine towns and their villages.

55.verse: Judah was also given Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah,

57.verse: Kain, Gibeah, and Timnah. There were ten towns and their villages.

58.verse: They were also given Halhul, Beth Zur, Gedor,

59.verse: Maarath, Beth Anoth, and Eltekon. There were six towns and their villages.

60.verse: They were also given the two towns of Rabbah and Kiriath Baal (also called Kiriath Jearim) and their villages.

61.verse: Judah was given these towns in the ·desert [wilderness]: Beth Arabah, Middin, Secacah,

62.verse: Nibshan, the City of Salt, and En Gedi. There were six towns and all their villages.

63.verse: The ·army [people; sons] of Judah was not able to ·force [drive] out the Jebusites living in Jerusalem, so the Jebusites still live among the people of Judah to this day.

1.verse: Land for Ephraim and Manasseh - This is the ·land [allotment] the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Joseph received. It started at the Jordan River near Jericho and continued to the ·waters [springs] of Jericho, just east of the city. The border went up from Jericho to the ·mountains [hill country] of Bethel [located northwest of Jersusalem].

2.verse: Then it continued from Bethel ·(also called Luz) [or to Luz] ·to [crossing over to] the Arkite border at Ataroth.

3.verse: From there it went west to the ·border [territory] of the Japhletites and continued to the area of the Lower Beth Horon. Then it went to Gezer and ended at the sea.

4.verse: So Manasseh and Ephraim, sons of Joseph, received their ·land [inheritance].

5.verse: This is the land that was given to the ·family groups [clans] of Ephraim: Their border [of their inheritance] started at Ataroth Addar in the east, went to Upper Beth Horon,

6.verse: and then to the sea. From Micmethath [on the north] it turned eastward toward Taanath Shiloh and ·continued eastward [or passing by it on the east] to Janoah.

7.verse: Then it went down from Janoah to Ataroth and to Naarah. It continued until it touched Jericho and stopped at the Jordan River.

8.verse: The border went from Tappuah west to Kanah ·Ravine [Valley; or Brook] and ended at the sea. This is all the ·land [inheritance] that was given to each ·family group [clan] in the tribe of the Ephraimites.

9.verse: ·Many of the towns were actually within Manasseh’s borders, but the people of Ephraim got those towns and their villages […and the cities set apart for the sons of Ephraim in the midst of the inheritance of the sons of Manasseh, all the cities and their villages].

10.verse: The Ephraimites could not ·force the Canaanites to leave [drive out the Canaanites living in] Gezer, so the Canaanites still live among the Ephraimites today, but they became ·slaves [forced laborers] of the Ephraimites.

1.verse: Then land was ·given [allotted] to the tribe of Manasseh, Joseph’s ·first son [firstborn; Gen. 41:51]. Manasseh’s ·first son [firstborn] was Makir [Gen. 50:23], the ·father of Gilead [or ancestor of the Gileadites]. ·Makir was a great soldier [or His descendants were great solders], so the lands of Gilead and Bashan were given to his family.

2.verse: ·Land [An allotment] was also given to the other ·family groups of Manasseh [sons/descendants of Manasseh, by their clans]—[the sons/descendants of] Abiezer, Helek, Asriel, Shechem, Hepher, and Shemida. These were ·all the other sons [the male descendants] of Manasseh son of Joseph.

3.verse: Zelophehad was the son of Hepher, who was the son of Gilead, who was the son of Makir, who was the son of Manasseh. Zelophehad had no sons, but he had five daughters, named Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.

4.verse: They ·went to [presented themselves before] Eleazar the priest [14:1; 19:51; 21:1] and to Joshua son of Nun and all the leaders. They said, “The LORD told Moses to give us land ·like the men received [among/or along with our brothers; Num. 26:33; 27:1–7].” So ·Eleazar [or Joshua; he] obeyed the LORD and gave the daughters ·some land [an inheritance], ·just like [or among] the brothers of their father.

5.verse: So the tribe of Manasseh had ten sections of land ·west of the Jordan River and two more sections, [in addition to] Gilead and Bashan [12:3–4], on the east side of the Jordan River.

6.verse: The daughters of Manasseh received ·land just as the sons did [an inheritance among/along with his sons]. Gilead was given to the rest of the ·families [sons; descendants] of Manasseh.
